title: R42524
content: Broadband deployment is crucial for regional economic development and job creation, especially in rural America where infrastructure costs are high and population densities are low. The federal government has historically supported rural telecommunications providers to improve broadband access, with an estimated $24 billion needed for further investment. Two federal programs currently fund broadband in rural areas. Two federal programs, the Rural Utilities Service (RUS) and the Universal Service Fund (USF), direct money to fund broadband in rural areas. The 113th Congress may assess how to shape the evolution of these programs, with potential amendments to the RUS broadband loan program and significant reforms to the USF. Congress is overseeing these reforms in the current climate of budget deficit reduction. In the current climate of budget deficit reduction, Congress is evaluating federal investments in broadband to efficiently deploy it in rural America. The Rural Utilities Service (RUS) offers various telecommunications and broadband programs, including loans, grants, and loan/grant combinations. Some programs focus on broadband infrastructure deployment, while others have evolved to support broadband-capable services. The Rural Utilities Service (RUS) offers telecommunications and broadband programs to support rural areas. Issues and criticisms arise during congressional consideration of these programs. The goal is to assist rural communities in becoming self-sustaining and economically thriving. Despite efforts, broadband access in rural areas remains inadequate compared to urban areas. Since 1934, the FCC has aimed to provide a nationwide wire and radio communications service at reasonable charges, leading to the universal service concept. This concept ensures telecommunications services are available to all Americans, including those in rural areas, through cross subsidies. The Telecommunications Act of 1996 established a universal service fund to ensure access to advanced telecommunications services nationwide. This replaced the complex system of cross subsidies that supported universal service goals before the breakup of the Bell System. The Telecommunications Act of 1996 established a universal service fund to ensure access to telecommunications and information services nationwide, including for low-income consumers, rural areas, and schools at discounted rates.
